meta.description: A measure of how hot or cold the water is, measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit.
meta.reason: Changes in temperature affect biological activity. Each species has a preferred range. Temperature also affects water chemistry; for example, warmer water can dissolve more minerals but holds less dissolved gas.

meta.description: A measure of water's acidity or alkalinity.
meta.reason: pH is affected by changes in water chemistry and can be an important indicator. pH also affects the solubility of metals, which can make water more toxic.

meta.description: A measure of oxygen in the water.
meta.reason: An important indicator of a water body's ability to support aquatic life. Too little or too much oxygen can harm aquatic organisms.

meta.description: A measure of water's ability to conduct an electrical current.
meta.reason: Bodies of water usually have a baseline conductivity range. Significant changes may indicate a pollution event, as conductivity is affected by salts and other dissolved compounds.

meta.description: A measure of dissolved salt content in water. Affects conductivity.
meta.reason: For organisms not adapted to changes in salinity, fluctuating levels can cause stress. Each organism is adapted to the water body's usual salinity range.

meta.description: A measure of the relative clarity of the water, typically measured in NTU.
meta.reason: High turbidity reduces light penetration. Particles also provide places for bacteria and other pollutants to attach.
